{{Infobox ethnic group | group = El Molo | image = | image_caption = | population = 2,840<ref name="Ethnelo"/> | region1 = {{flagcountry|Kenya}} | rels = [[Waaq]], [[Christianity]] | langs = [[El Molo language|El Molo]], [[Samburu language|Samburu]] | related = [[Sakuye people|Sakuye]] • [[Gabra people|Gabra]] }} The '''El Molo''', also known as '''Elmolo''', '''Dehes''', '''Fura-Pawa''' and '''Ldes''', are an ethnic group mainly inhabiting the northern [[Eastern Province (Kenya)|Eastern Province]] of [[Kenya]]. They historically spoke the [[El Molo language]] as a mother tongue, an [[Afroasiatic languages|Afro-Asiatic]] language of the [[Cushitic languages|Cushitic]] branch, and now most El Molo speak [[Samburu language|Samburu]].
==History== The El Molo are believed to have originally migrated down into the [[Turkana Basin]] around 1000 BC from [[Ethiopia]] in the more northerly [[Horn of Africa|Horn]] region. Owing to the arid environment in which they entered, they are held to have then abandoned agricultural activities in favor of lakeside fishing.<ref name="Newman">{{cite book|last=Newman|first=James L.|title=The Peopling of Africa: A Geographic Interpretation|year=1997|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=0300072805|page=166|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=pDjlC1ws158C}}</ref>
Historically, the El Molo erected tomb structures in which they placed their dead. A 1962 archaeological survey in the [[Northern Frontier District]] led by S. Brodribb Pughe observed [[hieroglyphics]] on a number of these constructions. They were mainly found near springs or wells of water.<ref name="Pughe">{{cite book|last=Pughe|first=S. Brodribb|title=A Preliminary Report Concerning Problems on the Origins and Ages of Certain of the Man-made Structures in the Northern Frontier District of Kenya and Certain Regions of the Eastern Horn of Africa|page=24|url=http://google.com/books?id=updtAAAAMAAJ}}</ref>
==Demographics== The El Molo today primarily inhabit the northern [[Eastern Province (Kenya)|Eastern Province]] of Kenya. They are concentrated in [[Marsabit District]] on the southeast shore of [[Lake Turkana]], between [[El Molo]] bay and [[Mount Kulal]].<ref name="Ethnelo">{{cite web|title=El Molo|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/language/elo|publisher=Ethnologue|accessdate=14 December 2013}}</ref> In the past, they also dwelled in other parts of the Northern Frontier District.<ref name="Pughe"/>
According to the 2009 Kenya census, there were 2,840 El Molo residents.<ref name="Ethnelo"/> However, historians have noted that there are few "pure" El Molo left. Most group members are today admixed with adjacent [[Nilotic peoples|Nilotic]] populations, primarily [[Samburu people|Samburu]], with only a handful of unmixed El Molo believed to exist. Many El Molo speakers have also adopted cultural customs from these communities.<ref name="Svf">{{cite book|title=Safari, Volume 4|year=1973|publisher=News Publications|page=14|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5H4wAQAAIAAJ}}</ref> In 1994, there were reportedly only eight unmixed El Molo remaining.<ref name="Ethnelo"/>
==Language== The El Molo historically spoke the [[El Molo language]] as a native language. It belongs to the [[Cushitic languages|Cushitic]] branch of the [[Afroasiatic languages|Afro-Asiatic]] family.<ref name="Ethnelo"/>
According to ''[[Ethnologue]]'', among other sources, the El Molo language is nearly extinct and there may already be no remaining speakers of the idiom. Most group members have now adopted the [[Nilo-Saharan languages]] of their neighbours.<ref name="Ethnelo"/>
The El Molo language has no known dialects. It is most similar to [[Daasanach language|Daasanach]].<ref name="Ethnelo"/>
==Genetics== Recent advances in genetic analyses have helped shed some light on the [[ethnogenesis]] of the El Molo people. [[Genetic genealogy]], although a novel tool that uses the genes of modern populations to trace their ethnic and geographic origins, has also helped clarify the possible background of the modern El Molo.
===mtDNA=== According to an [[mtDNA]] study by Castri et al. (2008), the maternal ancestry of the contemporary El Molo consists of a mixture of Afro-Asiatic-associated lineages and Sub-Saharan haplogroups, reflecting substantial female gene flow from neighboring Sub-Saharan populations. A little over 30% of the El Molo belonged to the West Eurasian haplogroups [[Haplogroup I (mtDNA)|I]] (23%) and [[Haplogroup HV (mtDNA)|HV1]] (8%). Their frequencies of the rare I clade, which is believed to have originated in the Middle East, constitute a world high. The remaining El Molo samples carried various Sub-Saharan [[Macro-haplogroup L (mtDNA)|macro-haplogroup L]] sub-clades, mainly consisting of [[Haplogroup L3 (mtDNA)|L3*]] (26%), [[Haplogroup L0 (mtDNA)|L0a2]] (17%) and [[Haplogroup L0 (mtDNA)|L0f]] (17%).<ref name="Castrí">{{cite journal|title=Kenyan crossroads: migration and gene flow in six ethnic groups from Eastern Africa.|year= 2008|last=Castrí|pmid=19934476|url=http://www.isita-org.com/jass/Contents/2008%20vol86/12_Castri.pdf|volume=86|pages=189–92}}</ref>
===Autosomal DNA=== The El Molo's [[Autosome|autosomal]] [[DNA]] has been examined in a comprehensive study by Tishkoff et al. (2009) on the genetic affiliations of various populations in Africa. According to the researchers, the El Molo showed significant Afro-Asiatic affinities. They also shared some ties with neighboring Nilo-Saharan and Bantu speakers in eastern Africa due to considerable genetic exchanges with these communities over the past 5000 or so years.<ref name="Tishkoff2009">{{Citation | last = Tishkoff | title = The Genetic Structure and History of Africans and African Americans | journal = the American Association for the Advancement of Science | pages = 17| year = 2009 | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1172257 |display-authors=etal}}; Also see [http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/1172257/DC1 Supplementary Data]</ref>
==Religion== Many El Molo practice a traditional religion centered on the worship of [[Waaq]]/Wakh.<ref name="Ethnelo"/> In the related Oromo culture, ''Waaq'' denotes the single god of the early pre-[[Abraham]]ic, [[Monotheism|montheistic]] faith believed to have been adhered to by Cushitic groups.<ref name="Abdullahi">Mohamed Diriye Abdullahi, ''Culture and Customs of Somalia'', (Greenwood Publishing Group: 2001), p.65.</ref>
Some El Molo have also adopted [[Christianity]].<ref name="Ethnelo"/>

{{Infobox Union |name= FWCUI |country= [[Iraq]] |affiliation= Independent |members= |full_name= Federation of Workers Councils and Unions in Iraq |native_name= |image= [[Image:Fwcui.png|250px]] |founded |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Baghdad]], Iraq |people= |website= [http://www.uuiraq.org/ www.uuiraq.org] |footnotes= }} <!-- Include all unused fields for future use. See [[template talk:Infobox Union]] for usage. --> The '''Federation of Workers Councils and Unions in Iraq''' (FWCUI) is the second largest [[union federation]] in [[Iraq]].
The federation was formed by members of the [[Union of the Unemployed of Iraq]], which is connected to the [[Worker Communist Party of Iraq]] as a [[left-wing]] alternative to the [[Iraqi Federation of Trade Unions]]. The latter is currently the only legally recognized union federation in Iraq; it is closely connected to the [[Iraqi Communist Party]], an organization which opposed the US invasion of Iraq in 2003 but decided to work with the new political institutions established after the occupation.
* This "legal recognition" of one union federation over another is a violation of the International Labour Organisation's Convention 87 on Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise, to which Iraq and all the occupying powers are signatory.([http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20040113043852/http://www.ilo.org/ilolex/english/convdisp1.htm], look for Convention 87; [[Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise Convention, 1948]].)
The FWCUI opposes both the U.S.-led [[History of Iraq (2003–2011)|occupation of Iraq]] and the [[Islamist]] elements of the [[Iraqi insurgency (Iraq War)|Iraqi insurgency]], and it is often repressed by both the foreign and Islamist forces. Many [[anti-war]] movements around the world have provided venues for FWCUI speaker tours. A third labor formation known as the [[Federation of Oil Unions in Iraq]] also exists.
The FWCUI's members have led a number of [[Strike action|strike]]s, and are particularly strong around the [[Basra]] region.
==External links== {{Portal|Organized labour}} *[http://www.uuiraq.org/ Federation of Workers Councils and Unions in Iraq and the Union of the Unemployed of Iraq]

{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Filipinos in Singapore |image = |population = '''175,000''' (2013)<ref name="POEA">{{citation |url=http://www.poea.gov.ph/stats/statistics.html |publisher=Philippine Overseas Employment Administration |publication-place=Philippines |title=OFW Statistics |accessdate=2014-04-28 |date=8 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140423231541/http://www.poea.gov.ph/stats/statistics.html |archivedate=23 April 2014 |df= }}</ref> (pop) |popplace = |langs = [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]], other [[Languages of the Philippines|Philippine languages]], [[English language|English]] |rels = Predominantly [[Roman Catholicism]]{{·}}[[Protestantism]]{{·}}[[Islam]] |related = [[Filipino people]], [[Overseas Filipino]]s }} '''Filipinos in Singapore''' consists of citizens from the [[Philippines]] residing in [[Singapore]].
==Demographics== In 2004 most Filipinos in Singapore were domestic workers.<ref name=AFPGoogle>"[http://phys.org/news/2014-06-google-singapore-blog-filipinos.html Google removes Singapore hate blog against Filipinos]" ( {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6QV4MwEHV?url=http://phys.org/news/2014-06-google-singapore-blog-filipinos.html |date=2014-06-21 }}). [[Agence France Presse]]. June 20, 2014. Retrieved on June 22, 2014.</ref> By 2009, there were 163,090 citizens of the Philippines living in Singapore.<ref name="POEA"/> Between 2010 and 2012, about 45,450 Filipinos were newly hired into Singapore.<ref name="POEA"/>
The number of Singaporean citizens of Filipino origin is difficult to determine, since they are officially counted as members of the "Others" race by the [[Immigration and Checkpoints Authority]].<ref name="ICA">{{citation |url=http://www.ica.gov.sg/news_details.aspx?nid=12851 |publisher=Immigration and Checkpoints Authority |publication-place=Singapore |title=Response To "What About Malay Migrants"|accessdate=2014-04-28}}</ref>
As of 2007, an estimated 80,000 work as [[domestic helper]]s, with another 12,000 in the [[information technology]] industry.<ref name="OPS">{{citation |url=http://www.news.ops.gov.ph/sg2007-profile.htm |periodical=News |publisher=Office of the Press Secretary |publication-place=Philippines |title=Background of Singapore and Profile of Singaporean President S.R. Nathan |year=2007 |accessdate=2008-04-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080419105844/http://www.news.ops.gov.ph/sg2007-profile.htm |archivedate=2008-04-19 |df= }}</ref> This marks a slight rise from 1995, when roughly 75,000 domestic helpers from the Philippines were estimated to be working in Singapore.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/19/world/ramos-calls-the-filipino-maid-executed-in-singapore-a-heroine.html |title=Ramos calls the Filipino Maid Executed in Singapore a Heroine |periodical=The New York Times |date=1995-03-19 |accessdate=2009-07-27 |last=Shenon |first=Philip}}</ref> In recent years they have seen professional diversification, with others working as nurses, bank clerks, sales assistants in department stores, or entertainers.<ref>{{citation |periodical=The Philippine Star |title=The changing face of Filipinos in Singapore |url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleid=417049 |last=Certeza |first=Dodo |date=2008-11-18 |accessdate=2009-07-27}}</ref><ref name="ManilaTimes">{{citation |url=http://www.manilatimes.net/national/2009/jan/16/yehey/top_stories/20090116top6.html |date=2009-01-16 |accessdate=2007-07-27 |periodical=The Manila Times |title=OFW jobs in Singapore not in peril |first=Bernice Camille V. |last=Bauzon |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117013622/http://www.manilatimes.net/national/2009/jan/16/yehey/top_stories/20090116top6.html |archivedate=2009-01-17 |df= }}</ref> However, of those, only 27,000 were registered to vote in [[elections in the Philippines|Filipino elections]].<ref>{{citation |periodical=The Age |publication-place=Australia |title=Filipinos in Singapore to test online voting |date=2007-02-22 |accessdate=2008-04-11 |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/Technology/Filipinos-in-Singapore-to-test-online-voting/2007/02/22/1171733864963.html}}</ref>
The number of Filipino victims of [[human trafficking]] jumped by 70% in 2007 to 212 cases.<ref>{{citation |periodical=Manila Standard Today |title=Trafficking in Filipinos worsens in Singapore |url=http://www.manilastandardtoday.com/?page=politics3_feb5_2008 |date=2008-02-05 |accessdate=2008-04-11 |last=Caber |first=Michael}}</ref> By 2013, over 167,000 Filipinos resided in Singapore. That year, a [[Google Blogger]] account appeared, giving suggestions on how to harass Filipinos in Singapore. This account was deleted by Google.<ref name=AFPGoogle/>
Aside from residents, roughly 460,000 Filipino tourists came to Singapore in 2008.<ref name="ManilaTimes"/>
==Controversies==
===Philippines Independence Day 2014 incident=== In May 2014, plans to hold celebrations for the Philippines Independence Day were cancelled due to online criticism of holding it in [[Orchard Road]], Singapore's main shopping district.<ref name=BBC>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-28953147|title=Unease in Singapore over Filipino workers|publisher=BBC News|date=29 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/more-singapore-stories/story/filipino-group-cancels-plans-hold-independence-day-celeb|title=Filipino group cancels plans to hold Independence Day celebration|publisher=The Straits Times|date=May 27, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indonesiarealtime/2014/04/22/filipino-group-awakens-anti-foreign-anger-in-singapore/|title=Filipino Group Awakens Anti-Foreign Anger in Singapore|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=April 22, 2014}}</ref>
===Tan Tock Seng nurse incident/Edz Ello incident=== In January 2015, Ello Ed Mundsel Bello (also known as Edz Ello), a Filipino nurse working for [[Tan Tock Seng Hospital]] was sacked. He was then charged for posting anti-Singaporean remarks on his social media accounts in April in the same year.
His comments immediately went viral, leading to "netizens" lodging police reports against him. Right after his comments went viral, his employer [[Tan Tock Seng Hospital]], conducted internal investigations. He was also required to assist in police investigations. However, he only admitted to posting some of the offensive comments to both the hospital investigation team and the police force, he then claimed that his social media accounts were "hacked", with the "hackers" posting the offensive comments using his social media accounts.
Police investigations showed that all the comments were made by Edz Ello, and his account wasn't hacked as what he had told the police previously. Netizens also proved that this was not the first time that he had made such a post before this incident.
On April 7, 2015, Ello Ed Mundsel Bello was arrested and charged for 3 counts of subsequently lying to the police, and 2 counts of publishing seditious statements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2015/01/12/1412123/filipino-nurse-sacked-anti-singapore-comments|publisher=PhilStar|date=January 12, 2015|title=Filipino nurse sacked for anti-Singapore comments}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/more-singapore-stories/story/philippine-embassy-reminds-tan-tock-seng-nurse-watch-his|title=Philippine embassy reminds Tan Tock Seng nurse to watch his social media usage|publisher=The Straits Times|date=Jan 6, 2015}}</ref> This resulted in an online petition on Facebook to deport the nurse.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/why-filipino-nurse-had-be-sacked|title=Why Filipino nurse had to be sacked|publisher=AsiaOne|date=Jan 13, 2015}}</ref> On 21 Sept 2015, Bello was sentenced to 4 months' jail.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/edz-ello-jailed-four-months-disparaging-remarks-against-singaporeans|date=September 22, 2015|title='Edz Ello' gets 4 months' jail for seditious posts}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=May 2018}} {{confusing|date=October 2017}} {{Orphan|date=August 2017}} }} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox recurring event <!--Is there a better infobox?--> |name = Mysterious hair chopping incidents in India and Nepal |native_name = |native_name_lang = |logo = |logo_alt = |logo_caption = |logo_size = |image = |image_size = |alt = |caption = A sample of chopped braid from Kashmir |status = Ongoing |genre = Mystery, rumours, human or animal activities, Indian agencies |date = |begins = May or June 2017 |frequency = Weekly, alternately, monthly |venue = |location = |coordinates = |country = [[India]], [[Nepal]] |years_active = <!-- {{age|YYYY|mm|dd}} Date of the first occurrence --> |founder_name = <!-- or | founders = --> |last = <!-- Date of most recent event; if the event will not be held again, use {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> |prev = |next = |participants = |attendance = |capacity = |area = |budget = |activity = Braid chopping |leader_name = |patron = |organised = <!-- "organized=" also works --> |filing = |people = |member = |sponsor = <!-- | or sponsors = --> |website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> |current = |footnotes = }} Since June 2017 unexplained '''hair chopping''' or '''braid chopping incidents''' have been reported in India and Nepal. The first widely reported incident was on June 23, 2017: [[ABP News]] reported a woman from [[Bikaner district|Bikaner]], [[Rajasthan]], had her hair chopped by a 'witch' as she slept. Similar incidents were increasingly reported throughout India, particularly in the northern states of [[Delhi]], [[Bihar]], [[Haryana]], [[Uttarakhand]], [[Uttar Pradesh]], and [[Indian Administered Kashmir|Indian-administered Kashmir]].
==India== ===Rajasthan=== On June 23, 2017 [[ABP News]] reported a woman from [[Bikaner district|Bikaner]], [[Rajasthan]] had her hair chopped by a 'witch' as she slept.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://abpnews.abplive.in/videos/viral-sach-is-there-a-witch-who-chops-off-people-s-hair-while-they-are-asleep-642035|title=रात में लोगों की बाल काटने वाली 'चुड़ैल' का वायरल सच|date=2017-06-23|work=ABP News|access-date=2017-08-22|language=en-US}}</ref> Additional hair-chopping incidents followed, and fears of an epidemic{{snd}}particularly in Rajasthan{{snd}}soared. Incidents occurred not only at night but also during the day.
Three days before the June 23 event, a similar incident was reported in [[Piparcity|Pipad City]], [[Jodhpur]], where a girl's hair had been found cut when she awoke in the morning.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://m.bhaskar.com/news/RAJ-JOD-HMU-MAT-latest-jodhpur-news-043016-2841137-NOR.html|title=रात में बाल काटने की अफवाह या सच्चाई, पुलिस के लिए पहेली|date=2017-06-20|work=dainikbhaskar|access-date=2017-08-23|language=hi}}</ref> This news was first reported by [[Dainik Bhaskar]]. Along with the missing hair, the girl displayed injuries on other parts of her body.<sup>[which parts?]</sup> When police investigated, they found that the girl's hair had been cut by a blade. However, they were unable to find the culprit.
On July 6, 2017 the ''[[Hindustan Times]]'' reported that two girls from Rajasthan, aged 13 and 14 years old, and both unknown to each other, were victims of additional hair incidents.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://m.hindustantimes.com/india-news/rajasthan-s-scissorhands-panic-in-villages-after-ghost-chops-off-women-s-hair/story-bQ0ZHij1WVQGOeHTPzybaI.html|title=Rajasthan’s scissorhands? Panic in villages after ‘ghost’ chops off women’s hair| date=2017-07-06|work=hindustantimes.com/|access-date=2017-08-22|language=en}}</ref>
On July 8, 2017 the [[BBC]] reported that many western municipalities including [[Bikaner]], [[Nagaur]], [[Jaisalmer]], [[Barmer, Rajasthan|Barmer]], [[Jodhpur]], and [[Jalore]] had been affected by these incidents.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/hindi/india-40542956|title=अफ़वाहों से परेशान हैं राजस्थान की महिलाएं|last=राठौड़|first=सुमेर सिंह|date=2017-07-08|work=BBC हिंदी|access-date=2017-08-22|language=en-GB}}</ref>
===Uttar Pradesh=== In early August 2017, two cases were reported from [[Aligarh]] and [[Moradabad]]. Four cases were reported in [[Bulandshahr]]. But later [[Uttar Pradesh]] (UP) police and [[Delhi Police]] clarified that the incidents were only rumours.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/fresh-cases-of-mysterious-hair-chopping-surface-in-aligarh-moradabad-and-bulandshahr-uttar-pradesh-delhi-4783182/|title=Fresh cases of mysterious hair-chopping surface in Aligarh, Moradabad and Bulandshahr|date=2017-08-05|work=The Indian Express|access-date=2017-08-22|language=en-US}}</ref> According to [[The Indian Express]] news channel, around thirty cases were filed all over north India.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/fresh-cases-of-mysterious-hair-chopping-surface-in-aligarh-moradabad-and-bulandshahr-uttar-pradesh-delhi-4783182/|title=Fresh cases of mysterious hair-chopping surface in Aligarh, Moradabad and Bulandshahr|date=2017-08-05|work=The Indian Express|access-date=2017-08-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
On August 2, a 62-year-old woman was killed by angry villagers in [[Agra]] for being accused as a "witch" who cut the braids of girls. [[NDTV India]] reported this news on August 3, 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.ndtv.com/india-news/woman-branded-witch-killed-in-uttar-pradesh-amid-braid-cutting-scare-1733038|title=Woman Branded Witch, Killed In UP Amid 'Braid Cutting' Scare|website=m.ndtv.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-24}}</ref> UP police filed murder cases on two suspects who fled the city and were neighbors of the victim.
===Delhi=== On August 1, 2017 three women, unknown to each other and aged between 50 and 60, from [[Kangan Heri]] complained about being the victims of hair-chopping incidents on the same day. None of the women had seen their perpetrator, but when they fell unconscious and later woke up, they found their hair chopped.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/1046374/a-mysterious-braid-chopper-is-cutting-off-womens-hair-in-northern-india/|title=A mysterious "braid-chopper" is cutting off women’s hair in northern India|work=Quartz|access-date=2017-08-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Haryana=== Fifteen cases were reported in Haryana state. The women who were victims of these types of incidents said that they had witnessed "god-men", "witches" and "cat-like creatures". The police rejected these claims.{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}}
One such incident happened in [[Gurgaon]] on July 28, when a 60-year-old woman found her braid chopped when she awoke on the floor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.in/2017/07/31/mysterious-incidents-of-womens-braids-being-chopped-off-spreads_a_23057298/|title=Mysterious Incidents Of Women's Braids Being Chopped Off Spreads Panic In Haryana Villages|date=2017-07-31|website=Huffington Post India|access-date=2017-08-24}}</ref> She made claims that a thin man came to her doorsteps with a trident in his hand. She claims she asked him to leave, but he reappeared, which led her to fall unconscious. The police filed the case and entered it in the Daily Diary.{{Explain|date=January 2018}}
===Jammu and Kashmir=== In this occupied region of India, there have been more than 200 incidents of women being attacked and often knocked unconscious by men in balaclavas, who then chop off their traditional hair braids. Officers had no solid leads or suspects, and [[Kashmir|Kashmiri]] police had to respond to a surge of revenge attacks by vigilantes armed with knives, [[Cricket bat|cricket bats]], and iron rods.
The initial police response to the braid attacks, which mainly occurred inside people's homes, was to suggest the victims were suffering from hallucinations. This drew criticism from the government-run Women's Commission, and they began serious investigations but no arrests have been made.{{when|date=May 2018|need a citation and an as-of to date it.}}
Tasleema Bilal, a 40-year-old woman whose hair was recently{{when|date=May 2018}} cut off while she was in her home in [[Srinagar]], the region's main city, said that she tried to remove the attacker's mask before escaping, leaving her hair behind. Other women have said that they were knocked unconscious with a mysterious chemical spray that authorities have yet to identify.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/mysterious-braid-chopping-bandits-have-kashmiris-in-panic-1.3646003|title=Mysterious braid-chopping bandits have Kashmiris in panic|last=Hussain|first=Aijaz|date=2017-10-24|work=CTVNews|access-date=2018-03-17|language=en-CA}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/indiahome/indianews/article-5013827/Armed-vigilantes-Kashmir-fight-hair-chopping-bandits.html|title=Armed vigilantes in Kashmir fight hair-chopping bandits|work=Mail Online|access-date=2018-03-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.apnews.com/892d2948287b4a3fb230f9597c654d1f|title=Mystery attacks chopping women's hair raise panic in Kashmir|work=AP News|access-date=2018-03-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
Kashmiris have alleged the attacks are the "handiwork of Indian agencies" trying to intimidate the portion of Kashmir's population that opposes Indian rule.{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} Residents are also suspicious of the Indian authorities, and some have accused soldiers and police of staging the attacks or protecting those responsible. In many incidents, the police and army appeared to aid the braid choppers in escaping by taking and saving them from public vigilantes.<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/24/women-living-fear-braid-chopping-bandits/</ref>
On October 22, 2017, [[Arab News]], a Saudi Arabian news agency, reported that around 100 women in [[Kashmir]] have been victims of hair-chopping incidents<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/1181506/world|title=Mystery ‘braid-chopping’ cases add panic to trauma in Kashmir|date=2017-10-22|work=Arab News|access-date=2018-03-17|language=en}}</ref>.
==Religious responses== {{Expand section|date=January 2018|the cultural importance of a woman's hair (and the act of removing it) in these regions.}}
===Hinduism=== In the June 23 case, the victim's legs and hands had a ''[[Trishula]]'' mark,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://abpnews.abplive.in/videos/viral-sach-is-there-a-witch-who-chops-off-people-s-hair-while-they-are-asleep-642035|title=रात में लोगों की बाल काटने वाली 'चुड़ैल' का वायरल सच|date=2017-06-23|work=ABP News|access-date=2017-08-22|language=en-US}}</ref> linking the incident to Hinduism. However, no Hindu religious leaders have responded to this detail.
===Islam=== Some [[Indian Muslims]] have also been victims of these types of incidents. Some Islamic scholars stated that these incidents are being executed by mischievous elements in society.
==Change in the rumor== On August 19, a report from [[Dainik Bhaskar]] changed the discussion surrounding these events. The report clearly proved that there was no such evidence of a witch or a ghost being responsible. In this report, a man from [[Gwalior]], [[Madhya Pradesh]] caught an insect which was later suspected to be a [[dermestidae]], [[drugstore beetle]], [[rain beetle]] or [[varied carpet beetle]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://m.bhaskar.com/news/c-6-scarce-insect-found-claimed-to-be-the-hair-scrapping-beetle-gw0197-NOR.html|title=चोटी काटने वाला समझ पकड़ ली ये अजीब चीज, फिर ये सच्चाई आई सामने|date=2017-08-16|work=dainikbhaskar|access-date=2017-08-22|language=hi}}</ref> This insect is believed to feed on keratin found in hair and nails.{{explain|date=May 2018|How does finding a beetle prove anything?}}
A similar case occurred on August 9, when a man killed a [[Badger|honey badger]] accused of eating or chopping women's hair, but due to lack of evidence, this report faced negligence.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://hindi.oneindia.com/news/uttar-pradesh/women-suspect-an-animal-as-hair-cutter-418241.html|title=VIDEO: बाल काटने की अफवाह में भेंट चढ़ा 'बिज्जू'|work=hindi.oneindia.com|access-date=2017-08-23|language=hi}}</ref>
On August 17, a report from [[Manpur, Bhopal|Manpur]], [[Madhya Pradesh]] had several eyewitnesses. The incident happened around 4 pm as the victim was sitting outside her house. She suddenly felt that her hair was being cut off. Her screaming brought the attention of her grandmother, who saw that her hair was being cut off, but she did not see anyone do it. Her grandmother quickly caught her fallen hair and the cutting stopped. Later the grandmother discovered an unusual detail. She noticed that as she picked up and held the hair, the rest of her granddaughter's hair was sheared, except for the exact number of hairs she held.{{Explanation needed|date=January 2018}}<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.firstwall.com/news/top-news/newstrack/e83d867fea5d37b504c196dd57bf44cb?ref=fw-sim|title=चोटी काटने के मामले में नया मोड़, जितने बाल हाथ में आए बच गए बाकि गिर गए नीचे|work=firstwall|access-date=2017-08-23}}</ref>
